pros:
For many reasons, this is the best place I have worked during my career. My colleagues are smart, dedicated, and hard-working, and I genuinely like them as people, in addition to appreciating their steady commitment to advancing Project HOPE's work around the world. For HQ staff, we have a surprising amount of interaction with our colleagues in the field, compared to other organizations, and that really helps stay inspired to do our best.

The organization has undergone a transformation in the past few year, from one heavily reliant on GIK to increasingly impressive development programming, and the senior leadership team in constantly focused on growing our impact, funding, and recognition. As our development programming has increased, it has been exciting to see our footprint expand into more areas, whether mental health, or innovative health worker trainings in Covid prevention and treatment.

Our benefits a few years ago were ok, but in the past couple of years, they have expanded and become very competitive. We have excellent paid time off (starting with 13 days vacation, 5 personal days, 3 floating holidays, 12 standard holidays, COVID leave, and last year, paid family leave was introduced, varying from 8-12 weeks depending on tenure.)

I work in DevComms. While we are frequently under intense pressure between high revenue goals and various emergency responses that can impact our work a great deal, it is also a team that has been steadily growing as part of a 4-year strategic plan, contributing additional funding and raising more awareness for the organization with every passing year. Our leader is strongly supportive of work life balance, while also challenging us to do our best for the organization. And the team is full of people who are smart, creative, and who bring their best to work every day.
cons:
The organization has undergone rapid growth in the past several years, and sometimes processes and infrastructure haven't yet caught up. This is a known issue and is being addressed over time. But someone who expects to come into a position with everything laid out and ready for them, every process fully baked, will be disappointed. On the other hand, people who love to build things and solve problems can really thrive.

Like working at other international orgs that respond to emergencies, it can be stressful to have work disrupted, sometimes multiple times a year, to pivot to an emergency response. It means other projects and efforts can go off track, and important but less urgent work gets delayed. It just goes with the territory.

Several reviewers, particularly on 2/3/22, make demeaning and untrue comments about DevComms team members in their reviews. I am glad that they are now former colleagues, as their behaviors and attitudes are indeed toxic. Where I think the organization can improve on this front is to take action more quickly and forcefully when team members are underperforming or showing a pattern of working to maliciously undermine their colleagues. If you're considering joining the team, you can feel confident that our best days are yet to come.

review_title: Toxic DevComm Culture is Opposite of Code of Ethics, but Condoned
pros:
- Many talented, passionate colleagues across Global Health & Emergency Response teams are improving lives and serving communities worldwide. They work tirelessly to advance the organization's mission. EVP, Directors and Managers are supportive and great to engage with, always pleased to collaborate, educate and advance good work together. The strong leaders and cohesive teams are driving growth. New Domestic program is but one example of excellence here.
- World-class global health leader serves as Chief Health Officer, a 21-year CDC veteran. An expert and compassionate leader. Great teacher and true humanitarian.
cons:
As accurate 1-star reviews posted in 2020 describe, steer clear of the revolving door that is Project HOPE's Development & Communications ("DevComm") department. Especially if you're a Communications expert or strategist who believes in best practices.

There is a serious problem causing toxic conditions, negative staff experiences and the highest turnover rates I've ever seen. Rather than fostering a spirit of solidarity, trust and collaboration, the team is managed in a dated, negative top-down manner. This culture favors a stunning degree of back-stabbing, pitting teams and good people against one another, weaving an "us vs. them" mentality toward colleagues (including toward Global Health, Health Affairs, others) rather than a unified, healthy fabric. Disrespectful behaviors and attitudes are the norm and condoned (don't be fooled by cheery group calls and emails that are performative, acting as though everything is fine when others are watching). In this culture, disparaging and misrepresenting people, their ideas, work and character are common, including existing staff (leadership team included) and people who left the organization. If you are accustomed to a professional workplace and normal standards of professionalism, prepare for culture shock.

This DevComm pattern began long before I joined Project HOPE. I was assured during interview stages that "the old PH" had some bad seeds who had to go, and that "the new PH" was cleaned up and full-speed-ahead. Unfortunately, the truth is that many talented, expert and mission-driven professionals leave because serious DevComm management and culture problems do not get addressed. 

As 2020 reviews note, HR, Legal and the Senior Leadership Team, including the CEO, are well aware of the DevComm problems. Many concerns have been raised over recent years, prior to and during my tenure. Leadership did not respond to staff concerns, including from some highest performers. Many talented employees thus left over a relatively short time. This included: three media personnel in three weeks, four in four months (i.e. the entire media department). Other losses in 2021 included two great fundraising professionals on the Development team, beloved by colleagues. Other staff left in 2020. I understood a series of sudden, startling firings occurred before my arrival. It became hard to count how many people left DevComm.

Importantly, there **are** several good, talented, positive professionals on Project HOPE's DevComm team. The toxic workplace issue is limited to an influential small few but has ripple effects that harm the entire organization. Staff can't understand why such problematic behavior is condoned, despite repeatedly flashing red on Senior Leadership's radar. Based on what one Senior Leader told me, the issue reached Board-level awareness before I joined the organization.

review_title: Good but a lot of room for improvement
pros: There is are great opportunities to blaze your own path if you have the drive and can articulate a vision. Along the same lines, the organization has a lot of resources that you can work to obtain and propel yourself and others forward. Once you connect with a colleague in-person, they are very easy to get along with and work with. It has a great family feeling and the organization is loyal to its employees. A very strong board of directors provides many resources and insight.
cons: Many employees are simply comfortable working there and dont seemed motivated to propel the company - this can be explained by the fact that most employees are interested in doing the bare minimum. The CEO is very hard to work with and seems to micro-manage everyone when he doesnt even have the time. There is no COO and many managers are left to scrap with the CEO. There is too much telecommuting and this makes it very hard to get things done. The work/life balance is "life" heavy for all employees. The brand seems to be diluted by the many different facets of the organization - I would greatly suggest a re-alignment so that employees and donors alike can better understand the breadth and depth of the organization.

pros: Project HOPE has an important mission and wonderful people working hard every day. They are passionate about what they do.  There are some new people there who have brought new energy to their programming.
cons: PH operates like a family-run business. There are few rules and policies, no code of conduct, and decisions are made based on who you like and who likes you. There is no job security because they can't raise the money they need.  Nowhere is this more obvious than on the Development team, which is a horror movie on a good day and the scariest place I've ever worked. The leadership works from home on the other side of the country so they have no relationship with their staff and no idea what's happening. They are constantly "reorganizing" so that the team is "fit for purpose" - you can see the evidence by the number of people who've been shoved out in the past 18 months. They are mean and vindictive. It is without question one of the most toxic, venomous work environments in town. People are in constant fear of being berated or screamed at, and of losing their jobs.

pros: Project HOPE is a positive work environment. The organization encourages participation at all levels of the organization and supports thinking out of the box. It welcomes those individuals who are willing to work hard for the betterment of supporting global health care. The Senior leadership is new, smart and aggressive. The Board of Directors is very supportive of the staff and the organization and willing to make introductions and participate at all levels. Project HOPE is looking for employees who want to move the mission forward and welcome ideas and strategies to support this action. This is a fast paced environment and is well suited to those who are passionate about health and willing to give it their all.
cons: If you want a 9-5 job that is rote, this is not the place for you. Like all organizations that are growing, there are "growing pains." But it allows all to be creative and provide ideas to move the organization forward.

pros: Some of the projects around the world are seeing real impact - it's great to feel apart of something good.
cons: HQ is a 2 hour drive from Bethesda with only a small staff in the Bethesda office. We were "encouraged" to make the drive out to HQ on a semi-regular basis as the folks in Millwood were unwilling to come to the Bethesda office. Therefore, we never got face time with management. HOPE is going through a transitional period and there's potential for a strong organization after that, but until then, they operate an international NGO like a local, family-run foundation.

pros: Most of the staff i.e. not the leadership are kind, generous and hard-working colleagues
cons:
I wouldn’t recommend this organization to anyone for any purpose. Do not go work there, and more importantly do not donate your time or money to them. They have a complete and total lack of respect for their donors and employees. Employees are seen as disposable and treated with total disrespect.

The senior leadership team is without morals or ethics, they lack leadership and will buckle to the whims of a board who also seem to want to drive this organization into the ground. They're a group of misguided leaders who are unwilling to do the right thing this is particuarly true on the development team. The development team is always chasing a dollar without any real business strategy or plans of any kind and it’s usually at the expense of their employees who are terminated, pushed out, laid off due to “fit for purpose” or other reasons that are generally without merit and are at the impulses of a reactive leader. Some of the “leaders” regularly ask for loyalty pledges from staff and balk when the staff won't commit themselves to the leader personally. This is the case most often on the development team. 

In addition to their lack of morals, every one of these senior leaders of the organization are underqualified and not even welcome in the leadership circles of the Humanitarian Aid community. Some of the leaders spend most days playing a political game with each other usually focused on undermining their colleagues and creating drama aimed at getting direct reports to infight. HR is not comprised or lead by certified SHRM professionals and don't seem to understand basic HR principles, not the least of which include establishing a code of conduct, or, more importantly, confidentiality.  HR regularly shares private conversations with each of the aformentioned "leaders" when staff who - often in seeking solutions - rightfully believe they should be able to go to their HR department with concerns about the actions and behaviors of their peers and leaders. The nicest thing I can say about the general counsel is that she’s overworked but without political capital and therefore bends to the urges of these other leaders and is often left to clean up their messes. 

Employees are regularly berated, shouted and cursed at by the some of these so called "leaders" particularly in development and by other development staff who view themselves as “above the law”. The organization does not hold its leaders accountable for their actions, which in turn has led to an “every man for himself” cutthroat environment.  The development team is constantly jockeying to get in front of the board while also bad mouthing and fighting with peers and the CEO. The Global Health team is the only one in the organization with a leader who has any sense of morals and willingness to do good on behalf of the organization. 

Be sure to check Project HOPE’s 990s carefully as they are grossly inflated and a completely inaccurate picture of the dire financial straits this organization is in. In-kind gifts do not equal cash!

In short, this organization will be run into the ground by an egocentric board and the reactive and chaotic nature of these incompetent leaders who are too busy worrying about themselves to worry about the well-being of a 61-year-old organization or its employees and the people they are trying to serve.

review_title: An NGO that seems to be struggling with its footing
pros: One of the greatest attributes of Project HOPE is the mission it strives to serve; Health Opportunities for People Everywhere. Whether you are on the ground directly supporting an initiative or working in the Millwood Headquarters, you feel like you are part of something big. While I worked at HOPE, it responded to several disasters bringing supplies, education, and comfort to the areas it served. Project HOPE's long, rich history of missions and initiatives that began when it was formed in 1958 is something to be proud of and often sparks conversation about its history and what it is doing now.
cons:
HOPE has this unique ability to attract talent, squeeze them for everything the foundation can get out of them,  and then send them on their way.  A prime example of this is the Development Department,  as it's often referred to as the "revolving door" of HOPE, as it saw the most turnover of any dpeartment within the foundation.  A second example of this is the Information Technology team. During my time at HOPE, we saw the departure of  over over 75% of the IT staff leave in the past six months. that seemingly drove just about everyone out of his department.  Lastly, the organization seems to lack a finanical steward. 

In my view, HOPE's staff,  particularly in the Millwood and Bethesda offices seem to have trouble staying motivated, which is likely related to the dark looming cloud of monetary trouble the foundation has continued to deal with. While working for HOPE, there were some layoffs and there was a constant fear of furlough.  While it's understandable that monetary challenges will lead to tough decisions, HOPE doesn't invest in its employees, it doesn't foster their growth, and it rarely promotes from within. If you are looking to grow yourself as an individual with an NGO and make a career out of, HOPE should only be considered as a stepping stone, not a long term employer.
